loan.name: Sayaad Haider

texts.en: Sayaad Haider lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has just graduated from school. During the school time, he was worked in a tailor shop. Now he has opened a tailor shop for himself. He wants to expand his business so he has requested an individual loan to buy new sewing machines and make his shop bigger to attract more clients and make a good monthly income to help his family. He is happy with all members of his family.

loan.use: To buy new sewing machines

loan.name: Chingiz

texts.en: Chingiz (his father is pictured) lives in the town of Khachmaz, Azerbaijan. He was born in 1978. Chingiz is single. He has been raising cattle for 10 years. Chingiz and his father need a loan of $850 to buy a cow for the business.

loan.use: To buy a cow

loan.name: Agashirin

texts.en: Agashirin A. was born in 1961and lives in the town of Khudat, Azerbaijan. He is married with four children. Agashirin has been selling phone accessories for 6 years. Now he needs a loan of $850 to buy phone accessories and improve the inventory of his business.

loan.use: To buy phone accessories

loan.name: Badirnisa

texts.en: Badirnisa M. is 39 years old and a mother of two children. She lives in Khudat, Azerbaijan. Now she needs a loan of $850 to buy produce and fruit for resale. Badirnisa has 7 years of experience in this business.

loan.use: To buy produce and fruit for her market stall

loan.name: Zarifa

texts.en: Zarifa A. is 38 years old. She is married and lives with her husband in the town of Khachmaz. She started a retail business 3 years ago. Zarifa would like a loan of $850 to buy goods to increase her inventory.

loan.use: To buy goods for resale

loan.name: Etibar

texts.en: Etibar D. is 42 years old and lives in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. He is married with two children. Etibar started raising cattle 8 years ago and would like a loan of $850 to buy another cow for his business.

loan.use: To buy a cow

loan.name: Fikrat

texts.en: Fikrat Babyev is a 33-year-old single man living in Khachmaz, Azerbaijan. He has 6 years of experience raising cattle and would like a loan of $850 to buy a cow for his business.

loan.use: To buy a cow

loan.name: Tarana

texts.en: Tarana (her husband is pictured) is 37 years old. She and her husband have four children and live in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. Her husband has 5 years of experience running a taxi business. The family would like a loan of $850 to buy spare parts and improve their taxi business.

loan.use: To buy spare parts for a taxi business

loan.name: Shirali

texts.en: Shirali is 36 years old and married with one child. They live in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. Shirali started selling hazelnuts 5 years ago and would like a loan of $850 to increase his inventory.

loan.use: To buy hazelnuts

loan.name: Aliya

texts.en: Aliya (her husband is pictured) is 27 years old and the mother of 2 children. The Isayevas live in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan, where they run a butcher shop. They need a loan of $850 to buy more cattle for this business.

loan.use: To buy a cow for slaughter

loan.name: Yusuf

texts.en: Yusuf H. is 35 years old, married and has two children. He lives in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. He is driving a taxi and supporting his family with this business alone. He applied to Normicro Beylagan Branch for the KIVA loan. He needs a loan in the amount of $500 to purchase necessary spare parts for his vehicle.

loan.use: To repair his vehicle

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: Invest in more ingredients for his food production and also buy more merchandise for his general store

loan.name: Eng

texts.en: Mrs. Eng K., 48, is a widow and lives with her three children in Kampong Chhang province. She runs a stall selling a variety of grocery products and earns approximately $6.20 a day of profit. Two of her daughters are garment workers earning around $70 dollars each month, and the other son works in Korea, generally earning around $700 dollars a month. Mrs. Eeng K. hopes to use this loan to purchase small cow to resell. People in provinces like buying small cows and reselling them when they grow up because it produces profit. Mrs. Eeng K. plans to use the profits from the cow to help her daughter open a stand selling a variety of spices. (Mrs. Eng K. is on the right hand side of the picture)

loan.use: To use this loan to purchase small cows to resell when they grow up

loan.name: San

texts.en: Mrs. San R. is 34-year-old and is married with three school-age children. She works selling clothes and utensils at Punle market, Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia. Every morning she has to get up very early in order to travel and open her shop, which is about thirty-five minutes from her house. With daily business activity, she can normally make around $3 each day of profit, while her husband can make only $2 per day from working as a dentist. Mrs. San R. has lately requested a loan amount of $1000 to purchase extra utensils and clothes to meet her large growing customer demand.

loan.use: To purchase extra utensils and clothes to meet her large growing customer demand.

loan.name: Chut

texts.en: Mrs. Chut C. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Klaeng commune, Seam Reap province, Cambodia. She and her husband work growing a variety of vegetables on her piece of farmland, making together about $2 each day only. All of her children are self-employed as fishermen, making collectively about $5 each day in revenue. Mrs. Chut C. needs this loan to buy an extra piece of farmland to increase her yield and another part of a loan will be used to extend her house because her children are growing every day.

loan.use: To extend her house because her children are growing every day.

loan.name: Yai

texts.en: Mrs. Yai Sophal, 38, is a seller of a variety of groceries, making on average $20 a day of income. Her husband, Mr. Mao Sophal, 40, is a motor-taxi driver and normally earns around $2 a day. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase more vegetables and food to meet the customer demand. (One of her daughter who is wearing grey cap is pictured in the back because Yai Sopal was unavailable).

loan.use: Purchase more groceries to meet the customer demand.

loan.name: Prum

texts.en: Mrs. Prum D., 24, is a mother of two little children and lives in ChamKar Tamoa village, Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia. She runs a stand at her home selling cooked beef and pork to the people in her area, making on average around $2 each day of profit. Her husband is meanwhile self-employed as a motor-taxi driver and typically makes about $4/day of income. Therefore, her mother-in law, who lives with her, also helps supplement her household by operating a karaoke business. Mrs. Prum D. hopes to use this loan to purchase wine and beer to serve in her stand, due to her customer demand, and the leftover of the loan she will use to buy more meat for her business. (Her husband, 29, is pictured because Mrs. Prum D. was unavailable)

loan.use: To purchase wine and beer to serve in her stand, due to her customer demand, and the leftover of the loan she will use to buy more meat for her business.

loan.name: Nigora

texts.en:
O. Nigora is 31-years-old and lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. She is married and has two children. Mrs.O. is engaged in the business of making and selling lepeshky (the national bread). She is also the accountant in the Jamoat.

Mrs.O. is requesting a loan of $825 to purchase flour for her bread.

loan.use: To purchase flour for making bread

loan.name: Juraboy

texts.en:
Juraboy M. lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. He is married and has four children. He has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2004. His past loans have enabled him to greatly improve his business.

He is engaged in the raising and selling of livestock .Mr. M. is also the machinist for the collective farm. Mr. M. is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase mixed fodder for his large flock.

loan.use: To purchase mixed fodder for raising livestock

loan.name: Ouk

texts.en: Mrs. Ouk M., 32, is a housewife who looks after the three children and cooks food for her family. She also has a small stand selling a variety of groceries, generally earning around $2 a day in Kampong Cham province. Her husband, Mr. Pun Pirun, 34, works as construction laborer every day and earns around $1.50 a day. This couple has three children, all of whom are students. This couple hopes to use this loan to expand her business by purchasing more groceries to sell in large amounts.

loan.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in large amounts.

loan.name: Khakima

texts.en:
Khakima M. lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. She is 45-years-old, is married and has four children. Mrs. M. has been a client of MicroINvest since 2004. She takes her business very seriously and believes strongly in the MicroInvest loan process.

Mrs. M. is involved in the sales of wholesale food products. She started her business from scratch and, thanks to the loans from MicroInvest, she has had her own trade outlet in the food bazaar for ten years. Mrs. M. is requesting a loan of $550 to purchase a wider assortment of food products to sell at the food bazaar.

loan.use: To purchase a wider assortment of food products

loan.name: Abdulla

texts.en: S. Abdulla was born in 1961 in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. He is married and has four children. He is primarily in the business of selling flour but also raises livestock . He trades in the bazaar and works with a wholesale flour supplier, permitting him to sell his flour at very attractive prices. Mr. Abdulla is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase additional flour inventory.

loan.use: To purchase additional flour for sales at the bazaar

loan.name: Pech

texts.en: Mrs. Pech S., 59, is married with 6 children and lives with her husband Mr. Bart Yun, 62. Together they work on their rice paddy, growing crops and vegetables, making on average around $2 a day. Additionally, three of Mrs. S.s children work in a factory, one is hairdresser, and two others work as waiters. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase a water pump, fertilizer and feed. If Mrs. Pech S. had a water pump, she would use it to pump the water from the lake into her field in the dry season so that they could produce more yields and water the crops. By buying a water pump, she can farm both seasons on her rice field. This couple also plans to raise fish when they have enough capital.

loan.use: Use loan to purchase water pump, fertilizer and feeds.

loan.name: Bashorat

texts.en:
Bashorat A. was born 1955 in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. She is married and has five children. Mrs.A. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2004.

She is engaged in selling clothing and shoes in a flea bazaar where her trade outlet is located . She has a good assortment of products and many repeat customers. Mrs.A. is requesting a loan of $625 to increase her inventory of goods.

loan.use: To increase inventory of clothing and shoes

loan.name: Dy

texts.en: Mrs. Dy S., 36, is married with three children and works as a farmer in Kampong Cham province, earning about $2 a day. Her husband, Mr. Chem Sary, 38, is on staff at the Planning Department in Kampong Cham province, making on average around $3 a day. As all of their children are studying and need more money, they hope to use this loan to purchase more plots of land to farm in order to generate more income to sustain their family and get a better life. In the future, they plan to raise more pigs if they have enough capital.

loan.use: to purchase more plots of land to farm

payment.comment:
Congratulations! Dy Sineth has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.
Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.
We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.
Sincerely, Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loan.name: Din

texts.en: Mrs. Din S., 35, works with her husband purchasing bananas from the growers and reselling them for a profit. They can make collectively about $8 each day. She has seven children. Some are students and some are enrolled in school. Mrs. Din S. hopes to use this loan to reinvest in her business by purchasing a larger quantity of vegetables to increase her income.

loan.use: to reinvest in her business by purchasing more vegetables to increase her income.

loan.name: Bin

texts.en: Mrs. Bin L. H., 31, works with her husband on her rice paddy growing rice crops and a variety of vegetables, each one making about two dollars per day from selling their rice crops and rice husks to an open-air market. Meanwhile, this couple has three children who all are enrolled in primary school. Mrs. Bin Lia H. has requested a loan amount of $400 to purchase her husband a motorcycle so he can operate a motor-taxi whenever he is available from his farming work. This will give her family another source of income.

loan.use: To purchase her husband a motorcycle to operate a motor-taxi

loan.name: Saidhonum

texts.ru:
Saidhonum M. lives in the Rudaki region. She is married and has 9 children. Saidhonum works in the private bakery where she bakes sambusas (Tajik patties) for the past 3 years. She has her own vendor spot near the local home improvement center Sadbarg. She wants to use the loan to buy an additional oven which will allow her to increase the daily production volume. This business is the main source of income for her family. By having a food production business Saidhonum has also created jobs and helps others earn a steady income. She plans to pay off the loan within 8 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

. 9 . 3 . . , . . , . , . 8 .

loan.use: To purchase an oven

loan.name: Mamazoid

texts.en:
I. Mamazoid is 40 years old. He is married with four children.
Mamazoid is a cattleman. He has been in this business for eight years. Currently he has two cows, one of which is a milk cow, and two heads of small cattle. Mamazoid also sells combustive lubricating materials. As a rule, he purchases from 600 up to 1000 liters of fuel and sells it during a period of one to two months. His wife and elder son help Mamazoid in his work. These two types of activities compose the main source of income for the family.
Mamazoid plans to purchase two more cows for raising and selling. For this purpose he requests 1000.00 US dollars for the term of 10 months. Mamazoid thanks all for their support and promises to pay the loan on time.

loan.use: To purchase two cows for raising and further sales.

loan.name: Umaraly

texts.ru:
Umaraly N. lives in the Rudaki region. He is married and has four children. He has no education. He makes his living by remodeling apartments and building custom homes. He has been also in the animal husbandry business which provides him with fresh milk and extra income by selling milk and breeding calves. Umaraly plans to use the loan to buy a calve as the prices for cattle go down in February, but in the fall he will be able to sell it for a higher and profitable price. The pay off term for the loan is 15 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

. 4 . . . , , , .. , , . 15 .

loan.use: To buy a calve

loan.name: Sadriddin

texts.ru:
Sadriddin S. lives in the Rudaki region. He is married and has 4 children. He works as a driver of a private taxi on a route Dushanbe - Gissar. He plans to use this loan to fix his car, Opel Vectra, that he uses for his business. Taxi business is the main source of income for his family. Aside from that, this activity gives the residents an opportunity to have fast and commodious mode of transportation.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

, ., 4 . - . Opel Vectra, . . .

loan.use: To fix the car

loan.name: Davlatbiby

texts.ru:
Davlatbiby was born in the town of Vahdat. She is 43 years old, is married and has 4 children. She is in the business of selling mainly men's clothes. She purchases her merchandise in the city of Dushanbe and resells it in Vahdat. She asks for this loan to purchase seasonal merchandise - men's shirts. This business allows her to provide for her family and give residents of such a small town an opportunity to purchase needed goods. She is planning to pay off the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

,43 , 4 . . . . , . , . 10 .

loan.use: To purchase seasonal goods

loan.name: Gulichahon

texts.en:
V. Gulichahon is 35 years old. She is raising 4 children alone.

Gulichahon sells clothing for kids in the local market. She is in this business for 8 years. Being the only bread-winner, she is working hard. As any mother, she wants her children to have everything they need and dreams that all of them shall have higher education. As there is a good demand for clothing for kids regardless of the season of the year, Gulichahon's business is rather stable, generating the main income and allowing Gulichahon to support her large family.

Now Gulichahon needs to increase her working capital to purchase new clothing to sell. For this she requests 950.00 US dollars for the term of 4 months. Having a positive credit history for several years with IMON, Gulichahon promises to manage the current loan without either delinquencies or violations.

loan.use: For purchasing new kids' clothing to sell

loan.name: Shodibek

texts.ru:
Shodibek J. lives in the Gissar region. He is 36 years old, is married, and has 3 children. He has a high school education. Shodibek is in the business of animal sales. For this reason, he plans to use the loan to purchase several young bulls. He generally buys animals on the market at a low price and then resells them at the same market at a higher price. This business gives him an opportunity to make money and provide for his family. Aside from that, his business also contributes to development of farming businesses in the area.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

. 36 , 3 . . - . . , , . . .

loan.use: To purchase several young bulls

loan.name: Khiev

texts.en: Mrs. Khiev S., 46, is a widow and owns a small booth, selling a variety of fruits, biscuits and some other provisions of food in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. Everyday she has to go the market to sell the fruits to the customers, normally earning around $5 a day of profit. She has three children. One son works in Ming Houy Company, earning a salary of $200 a month, and the other one is a motor mechanic, earning around $100 a month. Mrs. Khiev S. hopes to use this loan to purchase another stand in Phnom Penh for her younger daughter to operate, and with rest of the money she will purchase a motorbike to transfer her fruits to market and home. Moreover, this motorbike will br used as a taxi to transfer people in the daytime, to generate more income. She plans to raise pigs at her house, too.

loan.use: To purchase another stand in Phnom Penh for her younger daughter to operate.

loan.name: Shahodathon

texts.ru:
Shahodathon B. lives in the town of Vahdat. She is 40 years old, has a Bachelors Degree, and previously worked as a teacher. She is also married and has 2 children. She has been in the business of selling food products for the past 3 years. She plans to use the loan towards a purchase of a larger assortment of goods. Since this business is profitable, she is able to provide for her whole family. She is planning to pay off the loan within 8 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

. , ,40 . 2 . , , . . . , . 8 .

loan.use: To increase the assortment of inventory

payment.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 35653

loan.name: Nong

texts.en: Mrs. Nong B., 29, is married with two children in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She runs a stand in Neak Loeung, close to the ferry, selling rice, making around $5 each day of profit. Her husband, Mr. Suon Vanna, 36, is a taxi driver from Neak Loeung to Phnom Penh city, which generally earns $5 of profit a day. This couple hopes to use this loan to renovate their house. (This picture is Mr. Suon Vanna)

loan.use: This couple hopes to use this loan to renovate their house.

loan.name: Holishon

texts.ru:
Holishon M. lives in the Rudaki region. She is 40 years old, married, and has 2 children. She is in the business of cattle breeding and agriculture. These are the main sources of income for her family. Agricultural activities tend to be seasonal, so for this reason she is asking for loan to finance her cattle business. She plans to purchase a milk cow at a low price as in February they tend to drop down due to lack of food. This will give her an opportunity to get a good price and continuously have milk for both her family and for sales. She plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

, 40 , 2 . . . , . ,. . , . 12 .

loan.use: To purchase a milk cow

loan.name: Touk

texts.en: Mrs. Touk S., 32, is married with two children and lives with her husband and two little kids in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She runs a small stand at home selling vegetables, mainly morning glory, and typically makes about $2 each day of profit. Her husband is self-employed as a motor-taxi driver and can usually earn on average $2/day of income. In order to generate an additional profit for her household, Mrs. S. would like to use this loan to purchase pigs to breed and resell them for a profit.

loan.use: To purchase pigs to breed and resell them for a profit.

loan.name: Hani

texts.en: Hani, age 46, is married to M., who has no job. To support their living, and their 3 children, Hani opened a small shop where she sells groceries, vegetables, snacks, fruits, fried snacks, etc. She earns $20 a day with a small profit. To expand her business, she is requesting a loan of $100, so she can increase her income for her children's education. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within 12 months.

loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Mok

texts.en: Mrs. Mok B., 35, is a wholesaler, buying a variety of vegetables from Kampong Cham province to resell in Phnom Penh market, making on average about $13 a day of profit. Her husband, Mr. Em Phhal, 38, is banana seller. He purchases a large quantity of bananas from his community and resells them in the market, normally making $12 of profit. This couple has four children, two of whom are cleaners in Phnom Penh with a salary of $120 each a month. Mr. Phhal hopes to use this loan to expand his business by purchasing more bananas in his community and reselling in large quantity.

loan.use: Mr. Phhal hopes to use this loan to expand his business by purchasing more bananas in his community and reselling in large quantity.

loan.name: Rano

texts.ru:
Rano Kanjaeva lives in the Rudaki Region. She is 45 years old, married, and has 3 kids. She is in the business of cattle breeding: she buys animals at a low price and resells them at a higher price. This loan will be used for her business. She plans to purchase 2 young bulls at a low price because during this time of the year the prices go down due to lack of food for these animals. This will give her an opportunity to earn a higher margin by selling the bulls during the spring season at a better price. She plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

, 45 , 3 . , . . ,. . . 12

loan.use: To purchase young bulls

loan.name: Neneng

texts.en: Neneng, 33, is married to D. A., who works as a laborer at a workshop and earns $6 a day. To support their living, and their 3 children, Neneng sells sandals on credit door-to-door around places, earning $10 a week. She is a member of MBK and asking for a loan of $100 to add to her business capital. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Add to her business capital

loan.name: Asih

texts.en: Asih, 38, is a mother of 4 children. She sells "siomay," a steamed food with peanut sauce, from her house, earning $4 a day, while her husband, S., sells siomay door-to-door, earning $5 a day. She is a member of MBK and asking for a loan of $100 to add to her business capital, so she can increase her income for her children's education. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Add to her business capital

loan.name: Ipah

texts.en: Ipah, 33, is a mother of 3 children, ages 14, 5, and 1. Every day, she goes around the villages, door-to-door, selling cosmetics, such as powder, perfume, and shampoo, and is earning $4 a day. Her husband, A., sells fried bean sprouts at the market and earns $30 each week. She is a member of MBK and she is asking for a loan of $100 to expand both of their businesses. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Susanah

texts.en: Susanah, 24, is a mother of 2 daughters. She is married to C., who sells vegetables at the market, and earns $20 a day. To support her family's needs, she sells sandals on credit door-to-door around villages, earning $40 a month. She is a member of MBK and asking for a loan of $75 to add to her business capital. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Add to her business capital

loan.name: Rajabali

texts.ru:
Rajabali H. lives in Rudaki. He is 40 years old and is married with 4 children. He raises livestock and brings in additional money by providing repair services. These are main sources of income for his family. Rajabali applied for a loan to use it to expand his livestock: he plans to purchase the calves in February, when the prices are low. He will fatten them and will sell them in the spring at a higher price. He is planning to repay his loan within 15 months.

Translated from Russian by Jamilya & Keith Leitich, Kiva Volunteers.

, 40 , 4 . , . . . ,. . . 15 .

loan.use: Purchase of calves

loan.name: Uway

texts.en: Uway, 30, is married to O., who sells parsnip at their house and at the market, earning $10 a day. They have 3 children. To add to the family's income, Uway goes door-to-door selling sheets on credit, earning $30 a week. She is a member of MBK and is asking for a loan of $75 to add to her business capital. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Add to her business capital

loan.name: Yeng

texts.en: Mrs. Yeng C., 36, is married with three children and is a housewife who stays at home to look after the children and cook food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Vart Eedh, 40, owns a plot of land growing a variety of vegetables, making on average about $3 a day of profit. This couple wish to use this loan to purchase a water pump to water their crops, as in the dry season it is difficult without water. The rest of the money they will use to buy cashew nuts and resell them to sustain their family and provide a better life.

loan.use: This couple wish to use this loan to purchase a water pump to water their crops in the dry season.

loan.name: Rosmi

texts.en: Rosmi, 39, is married to Z., who works as a landless farmer, and does not have a regular income. They have a son, who has already married. Rosmi has a grocery store at her house where she sells food, groceries, flavoured ice, cigarrettes, etc., and can earn up to $20 a day depending on the number of customers. She is a member of MBK and is asking for a loan of $100 to buy more goods for her store. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Buy more goods for her store

loan.name: Odah

texts.en: Odah, 63, sells salty fish every day from her house, earning $7 a day, while her husband, A., sells the fish at the market, and earns $10 a day. She is a member of MBK and is asking for a loan of $75 to add to her fish business. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Add to her business capital

loan.name: Otih

texts.en: Otih, 33, is married to U., who works as a laborer and earns a very small income. To cover their living expenses and support their two children, Otih opened a grocery store at her house and earns $5 a day. She is asking for a loan of $75 to add to her business capital. She is a member of MBK and she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Add to her business capital

loan.name: Bibihursand

texts.ru:
Bibihursand H. lives in Vahdat. She is 48 and is married with 5 children. She has a secondary education. She works as a milkmaid. Besides that, she has been raising livestock for the past 6 years. With the proceeds of her loan, she plans to purchase calves, which she plans to fatten and then sell. This business is one of the most popular types of businesses in rural areas. Bibihursand plans to repay her loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Jamilya & Keith Leitich, Kiva Volunteers.

. 48 , , 5 . . . 6 . . . 12 .

loan.use: purchase of calves

loan.name: Busogo Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mariam K.. She is currently in the business of running a drug shop and is requesting a loan to buy more drugs to sell and boost business. Mariam is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 4 children ranging from age 3 to 14 and all of them go to school. Each week, Mariam makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. Mariam has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 450000 in order to by dental forceps and the loan was paid back on time.

Mariam is joined in her small group by Prossy N., Sylvia N., Sarah B., and Monica N.. Prossy N. has a business in poultry keeping and wants to carry out lumbering. Sylvia N. is currently operating a business selling snacks and wants a loan to expand her business. Sarah B. operates a drug shop business and wants to purchase more drugs to sell. Monica N. is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to increase her stock.

loan.use: To add stock to her drug shop

loan.name: Irawati

texts.en: Irawati, 26, is married to A. and has a 9-year-old child. A. works as a laborer at a construction site and earns a very small income. To support the family's needs, Irawati has a food stall where she sells snacks, ice, candies, etc., earning $6 a day. She is a member of MBK and is requesting a loan of $75 to expand her business, so she can increase her income for her children's education. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Nati

texts.en: Nati, 51, is a mother of 4 children. To support the family, she sells bags of ice from her house for $0.5 each and earns $3 a day. Her husband, M., sells vegetables, and earns $10 a week. She is requesting a loan of $100 to expand her business. She is a member of MBK and she will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Buguwa I A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sofia N.. She is currently operating a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase her stock. Sofia is 28 years old and is married to a farmer. She has four children, ranging from age 1.5 to 12 years old. Only one of her children attends school. Each week, Sofia makes approximately UGX 17000 in profit. With the extra profit she earns, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. Sofia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, to the amount of UGX 600000, to buy sacks of sugar. The loan was paid back on time.

Sofia is joined in her small group by Efrancee N., Jovia I., Agatha N., and Salama K.. Efrance N. has a business selling charcoal and wants to expand her business. Jovia I. is currently operating a retail shop and wants a loan to purchase more items. Agatha N. operates a retail shop and wants to add more stock. Salama K. is currently selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to increase her stock and improve her business.

loan.use: To invest in a retail shop business

loan.name: Salomatkhon

texts.ru:
Salomatkhon N. lives in Dushanbe. She is 35 years old and is married with two children. She has a secondary education. Salomatkhon sells food products. She has been in this business for three years. Salomtkhon wants to use her loan to purchase products such as flour, sugar, and oil, which will help her expand her business. Her business is the main source of income for her family. She plans to repay her loan within 8 months.

Translated from Russian by Jamilya & Keith Leitich, Kiva Volunteers.

. . 35 , 2 . . . 3 . (, , .) , . . 8 .

loan.use: Business expansion

payment.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 35675

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: to expand her brew business

loan.name: Nopi

texts.en: Nopi, 29, is married to A., who works at a construction site, earning $60 a month. Every day, Nopi sells clothes door-to-door on credit, and collects installment payments weekly. She can get $50 a week. She is a member of MBK and is requesting a loan of $75 to add to her business capital. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loan.use: Add to her business capital

loan.name: Buguwa Ii A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Deborah N.. She is currently in the business of selling fish and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Deborah is 45 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has five children, whose ages range from age 10 to 20. Her children go to school. Each week, Deborah makes approximately UGX 15000 in profit. With the extra profits she will make with the help of a loan, she hopes to be able to repay the loan and pay the school fees for her children. Deborah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, to the amount of UGX 300000, in order to start a wholesale business. Tthe loan was paid back on time.

Deborah is joined in her small group by Suzan I., Margret K., Esther N., and Aidah K.. Suzan I. has a business selling new clothing and wants to increase her stock. Margret K. is currently operating a local brewing business and wants to buy a brewing machine. Esther N. operates a farming business and wants to start trading coffee. Aidah K. is operating a retail shop and is requesting a loan to buy more sacks of sugar.

loan.use: to expand her fish business

loan.name: Suhartini

texts.en: Suhartini is 29, married, and a mother of two children. She goes door-to-door to sell children's clothing on credit, collecting installments weekly. She earns up to $10.00 a week. Her husband has a kiosk at the market where he also sells clothings, earning $20.00 a day. She will use this loan to expand her business.

loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Abdumahmad

texts.ru:
Abdumahmad was born in 1971, married and has been in the animal husbandry business for the past 10 years. He has a large piece of land attached to his house where he breeds his livestock. At this time he has four bulls and two cows. Last fall one of the cows gave birth to a calve and now Abdumahmad's family has fresh milk every morning.

His wife milks the cow and his children feed the animals and help their father clean up. After the bulls have grown he sells them and buys a new set of calves for continuous business.

Abdumahmad has been taking out loans since March 10, 2007 and has been successfully paying them off. He has also applied for a loan in Kiev to buy fodder for livestock and coal to heat the byre.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

,1971 ,, 10 . , . 4- . .

, . .

10.03.2007 . .

loan.use: To purchase fodder for bulls.

loan.name: Encum

texts.en: Encum is 43, married, and a mother of five children. She has a food stall in front of her house where she sells snacks, flavoured ices, fried snacks, and other food items. She earns $3.00 a day. Her husband has no fixed job so she must work hard to support the entire family. She will use this loan to expand her business.

loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Sultonmurod

texts.ru:
Sultonmurod A. is a resident of the Gissar region. He is 32 years old, married and has 4 children. He has a college degree. Currently he is making his living by selling groceries and is requesting a loan of 1500 somoni. Mr. A. is planning to use the money to purchase additional goods so that he can increase the variety of items his store offers for sale. He is hoping to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer.

. , 4. 32 . . . 1500 . . 12 .

loan.use: Increase of goods turnover

loan.name: Buguwa Ii B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Joy T.. She is currently operating a retail shop and is requesting a loan to buy a refrigerator. Joy is 36 years old and is married to a farmer. She has 3 children, ranging from 6 to 18 years old. Her children go to school. Each week, Joy makes approximately UGX 20000 in profit. With the extra profits she will make with the help of a loan, she hopes to be able to cater to her basic needs. Joy has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, to the amount of UGX 300000, in order to start a wholesale business. The loan was paid back on time.

Joy is joined in her small group by Tisame N., Pauline N., Rebecca B. and Hellen K.. Tisame N. has a business selling used clothing and wants to start up a clothing boutique. Pauline N. is currently operating a retail shop and wants a loan to open up another shop in town. Hellen K. sells shoes and wants to start up a retail shop. Rebecca B. has a fish selling business and wants to invest in her business with the loan.

loan.use: to invest in a retail shop business

loan.name: Dong

texts.en: Mrs. Dong S., 44, is married with five children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works selling palm sugar to a nearby market, while her husband is the one who is a palm sugar refiner. He has to get up very early in the morning to collect palm juice and start refining it. With this business activity, S. and her husband can collectively make around $4 per day of profit. Therefore, one of her children is a driver; another one is a bus-conductor; and the balance of their children are enrolled in school. S. and her husband would like to spend the rest of their time breeding pigs for additional profit, but they face a financial constraint. To do so, the couple would like to request for a loan to help them.

loan.use: To purchase pigs to raise for an addititional profit.

loan.name: Norn

texts.en: Mrs. Norn O., 38, is married with two children and works selling duck eggs to the people in her area and usually makes about $3.20/day in revenue. Her husband operates a carnival balloon dart game and generally makes around $5 each day of income. Mrs. Norm O. hopes to use this loan to purchase more carnival items for her husbands business. This will increase her entire family's income.

loan.use: To purchase more carnival items for her husbands business.

loan.name: Mutekanga A Group

texts.en: The group leader of this small group is Margret M.. She currently operates a stationary shop and is requesting a loan to purchase a photocopier. Margret is 46 years old and is married to an accountant. She has three children, ranging from 18 to 23 years of age. Her children go to school. Each week, Margret makes approximately UGX 60000 in profit. With the extra profit she will make with the help of a loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children Margret has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, to the amount of UGX 300000, in order to start a wholesale business. The loan was paid back on time. Margret is joined in her small group by Sawuya T., Salama N., Aidah F., and Aisha N.. Sawuya T. has a retail shop and wants to buy a refrigerator. Salama N. is currently operating a tailoring business and wants a loan to purchase a Nero machine. Aidah F. has a poultry business and wants to use the loan to expand it. Aisha N. sells new shoes and wants to increase her stock.

loan.use: To add in business and buy a photocopier

loan.name: Vorn

texts.en: Mrs. Vorn Ruom, 27, is a married with one little kid and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She works raising pigs on her piece of land and usually makes about $2 each day in revenue. Her husband works as a fisherman, making three dollars each day in revenue. Mrs. Von R. would like to ask for this loan to expand her livestock by adding more pigs. This will increase her familys income.

loan.use: Needs more pigs to expand her livestock.

payment.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Vorn Ruon start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loan.name: Mutekanga B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Cate N.. She is currently in the business of new clothing and is requesting a loan to start a retail shop. Cate is 46 years old and is married to a husband who is an accountant . She has 2 children, 1.5 and 4 years old. They do not attend school. Each week, Cate makes approximately UGX 30000 in profit. With the extra profit she will earn with the help of a loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. Cate has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, to the amount of UGX 250,000, in order to increase her stock. The loan was paid back on time.

Cate is joined in her small group by Lukia N. and Aisha H.. Lukia N. has a business in used clothing sales and wants to boost her business. Aisha H. is currently operating a drug shop and wants a loan to purchase more medicine to sell.

loan.use: to start up a retail shop business

loan.name: Roslinah

texts.en: Roslinah is 31, married, and a mother of two children. She sells kerosene from her house and earns $5.00 a day. Her husband also sells kerosene door-to-door around the villages and earns $6.00 a day. She will use this loan to add to her business capital.

loan.use: Increase business capital

loan.name: Ika Kartika

texts.en: Ika is 32, married, and has two children. Ika and her husband have a fish pond and get income from people who fish in their pond. They can earn up to $20.00 a week. They also sell food, such as instant noodles and coffee, and earn $30.00 a week with a small profit. She will use this loan to add to their business capital.

loan.use: Increase business capital

loan.name: Nia

texts.en: Nia is 25, married, and has one child. She makes and sells flavoured ice and instant beverages, earning $5.00 a day. Her husband sells vegetables and earns $15.00 a day. She will use this loan to add to her business capital.

loan.use: Add to her business capital

loan.name: Namuyingi Ii A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Catherine N.. She is currently in the business of running a drug shop and is requesting a loan to increase stock. Catherine is 27 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant farmer. She has 4 children ranging from age 4 to 10 and her children go to school. Each week, Catherine makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to meet the basic needs of her family. Catherine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to increase stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Catherine is joined in her small group by Zaina Nabire, Zaituni M. and Rovince N.. Zaina Nabire has a business in tailoring and wants to buy a new sewing machine. Zaituni M. is currently operating a hotel business and wants a loan to buy new hotel assets. Rovince N. operates a hotel business and wants to expand her business.

loan.name: Yuli

texts.en: Yuli is 23 and married. Everyday, she goes door-to-door to sell clothing and other household goods, such as towels, sheets, and blankets. She earns $10.00 a week. She will use this loan to expand her business.

loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Suwartini

texts.en: Suwartini is 32 and married. To support her family, she bakes and sells cakes, earning $8.00 a day. She sells her cakes door-to-door and also in neighborhood shops. She will use this loan to expand her business.

loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Arni

texts.en: Arni is 48 and a widow. Her husband passed away a long time ago, leaving her to support herself on her own. She collects and sells waste material, such as plastics and papers, earning a very small income. She will use this loan to expand her business.

loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Euis

texts.en: Euis is 22, married, and has a son. Everyday, she sells clothing door-to-door and earns $15.00 a week. Her husband sells vegetables at the market and earns $10.00 a day. She will use this loan to add to her business capital.

loan.use: Increase business capital

loan.name: Tuti

texts.en: Tuti is 27, married, and has two children. Tuti and her husband both collect and then sell waste materials, earning $40.00 a week. She will use this loan to add to her business capital.

loan.use: Increase business capital

loan.name: Namuyingi Ii B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Harriet N.. She is currently in the business of selling new shoes and is requesting a loan to expand and start a wholesale business. Harriet is 34 years old and is married. Her husband has a retail shop business. She has eight children, ranging from 2.5 to 16 years old. Her children go to school. Each week, Harriet makes approximately UGX 60000 in profit. With the extra profits she will earn with the help of a loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children Harriet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, to the amount of UGX 200000, in order to invest in her business. The loan was paid back on time.

Harriet is joined in her small group by Toplota N., Harriet M., Irene M., and Jesca M.. Toplota N. has a business selling coffee and wants to expand her business. Harriet M. is currently operating a catering business and wants a loan to boost her business. Irene M. operates a business selling used clothing and wants to increase her stock. Jesca M. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy new clothes to sell.

loan.use: to expand her business and become a clothing wholesaler

loan.name: Icah

texts.en: Icah is 33, married, and has two children. Everyday, she goes door-to-door to sell household goods on credit, earning $15.00 a week. Her husband is a butcher at the market who earns $15.00 a day. She will use this loan to expand her business.

texts.en: Wida is 37, married, and has two children. Everyday, she goes door-to-door to sell her sandals on credit, earning $4.00 a week. She will use this loan to add to her business capital.

loan.name: Rahim

texts.ru:
Rahim is one of MLF MicroInvest organization's successful clients since October 18th, 2007. His business is going very well which he has for the past 10 years. He is married and has seven children. His older sons are involved in the business. They help sort out the inventory and transport it to the vending point. Rahim has a regular supplier and clients from different regions. He does his business with confidence and pays off his loans in a timely manner. He has applied for a loan with Kiva to purchase another lot of inventory (almonds, raisins, peas and peanuts).

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

, 18.10.2007. , 10 . 7 . , , . . . .(,, )

Sarah is joined in her small group by Peninah N., Zainabu N., Robinah N., and Margret N.. Peninah N. has a retail shop and wants to buy a refrigerator. The group leader of this small group is Resty N.. She is currently in the business of cooking food and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Resty is 38 years old and is married to a school bursar. She has seven children, ranging from 5 to 18 years in age. Her children attend school. Each week, Resty makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits. With the extra profits she will make with the help of a loan, she hopes to be able to meet her basic needs Resty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, to the amount of UGX 200000, in order to buy a refrigerator. The loan was paid back on time.

Resty is joined in her small group by Miriam N., Janat N., Labetha M., and Jane B.. Miriam N. has a business selling clothes and wants to start a clothing shop. Janat N. is currently operating a hotel business and wants a loan to increase her capital. Labetha M. operates a business selling maize and wants to boost up her business. Jane B. is currently in the business of brewing local beer and is requesting a loan to buy a brewing machine.

loan.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 38 years old. He has three children. Two of them are studying in high school and the other one is in university. His elderly mother became his responsibility after his father's death. He has a small shop of glass sales. He applied to borrow $1200 to purchase new and different shapes of glass to sell and expand his project. He also wants to make some advertising to increase his income and save for a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loan.use: Purchase new and different shapes of glass

loan.name: Dayanat

texts.en: Dayanat was born in 1980. He is single and lives in Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. Mr. N. has three years of experience as a taxi driver. He is requesting a loan of $600 to buy spare automobile parts.

The group leader of this small group is Efrance N.. She is currently a wholesaler and is requesting a loan to start trading sweet potatoes. Efrance is 38 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has seven children, ranging from 3 to 17 years old. None of them attend school. Each week, Efrance makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits. With the extra profits she will earn with the help of a loan, she hopes to be able to buy new items for her home . Efrance has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, to the amount of UGX 250000, in order to enter into a bar business. The loan was paid back on time.

Efrance is joined in her small group by Ruth N., Ruth B., Eva N., and Margret M.. Ruth N. has a business in tailoring and wants to expand her business. Ruth B. is currently operating a hotel business and wants a loan to start a bar business. Eva N. operates a business of selling coffee and wants to boost her business. Margret M. is currently in the business of coffee selling and is requesting a loan to increase her stock.

loan.use: to expand her retail shop business

loan.name: Namuyingi Ii E Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jafat N.. She currently runs a retail shop and is requesting a loan to buy a refrigerator. Jafat is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has four children, ranging from 5 to 11 years old. Her children do not go attend school. Each week, Jafat makes approximately UGX 80000 in profits. With the extra profits she will make with the help of a loan, she hopes to build a house. Jafat has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, to the amount of UGX 150000, in order to increase her capital. The loan was paid back on time.

Jafat is joined in her small group by Aliyas M., Hadijah N. and Sarah N.. Aliyas M. has a business selling charcoal and wants to start a poultry business. Hadijah N. is currently operating a grocery store and wants a loan to expand her business. Sarah N. operates a retail shop and wants to increase her stock.

loan.use: to purchase a refrigerator

loan.name: Akmal

texts.ru:
Akmal has sufficient experience and is a scholar at his trade. He has been in the animal husbandry business for the past six years. His family helps him take care of the livestock. The cow house is located on a wide farm-yard near his house.

His current business is very stable and has a good capital turnover. His business consists of buying, feeding and growing and then selling of cattle. The profits grow more with each month and he uses part of the profits to support his family and the rest to reinvest into his business to buy fodder for the cattle. As you can see on the photo, the cow house is a bit small and Akmal wants to build a new one. In the future, he wants to increase the number of livestock, but there's a small problem with the premises. A credit counselor advised him to apply for a loan with Kiva. He hopes to receive a loan soon and promises that he will pay it off within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

, . 6 . , .

. , . , . . , . 10 .

loan.use: To repair the cow house and to build an additional premise.

loan.name: Butimba A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Catherine B.. She is currently in the business of milk selling and is requesting a loan to boost business. Catherine is 38 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 6 children ranging from age 10 to 20 and none of them goes to school. Each week, Catherine makes approximately UGX 12000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to meet the basic needs of the family such as clothes. Catherine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to increase on her capital and the loan was paid back on time.

Catherine is joined in her small group by Scovia N., Mariam N., Rose M., and Sylvia K.. Scovia N. has a business in selling new shoes and wants to start selling clothes. Mariam N. is currently operating a business in used clothing sales and wants a loan to expand business. Rose M. operates a business of milk selling and wants to increase her business. Sylvia K. is currently in the business of selling beans and sweet potatoes and is requesting a loan to increase stock and boost business.

loan.use: To expand milk business and make more profits

loan.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida (her sister is pictured) was born in 1969. She is married and has two children. Aida, along with her sister, breeds chickens, hens and turkeys. They are requesting a loan of $600 to purchase additional chickens, hens and turkeys to improve their business.

loan.use: To purchase chickens, hens and turkeys

loan.name: Butimba B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jane Basajabalaba. She is currently in the business of fish selling and is requesting a loan to increase her stock. Jane is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 6 children ranging from age 5 to 20 and her children go to school. Each week, Jane makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start constructing a house. Jane has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to increase her stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Jane is joined in her small group by Tetu N., Hajara B. and Miramba M.. Tetu N. has a business selling fish and wants to boost business. loan.name: Koy

texts.en: Mrs. Koy O., 38, is a mother of eight children and lives with her husband in Boeung Sna village, Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She and her husband work on a plot of land breeding pigs and then resell them to a nearby butchers, making collectively about $10 each day in revenue. This couple has eight children. Three of them are employed by a garment factory; two others are unemployed; and the balance of their children are married and live outside the family home. Mrs. Koy O. hopes to use this loan to increase the number of pigs to meet her client demands.

loan.use: To increase the number of pigs to meet her client demand.

payment.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Koy Ouk and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loan.name: Kit

texts.en: Mrs. Kit V., 52, is married with 5 children and works as a farmer making on average about $3.50 a day of profit. Her husband, Mr. Ka Sa, 54, owns a plot of land growing a variety of vegetables and normally earns around $2 a day. This couple has five children. Two are car mechanics earning around $200 a month and three others are students. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase a plot of land to grow some vegetables in order to gain more profit. In the future, this couple plans to open a garage for their son.

loan.use: This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase a plot of land to grow more vegetables.

loan.name: Butimba C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jalia N.. She is currently in the business of fish selling and is requesting a loan to start a clothing business. Jalia is 32 years old and is a widow. She has 6 children ranging from age 2 to 10 and her children go to school. Each week, Jalia makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Jalia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to increase her stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Jalia is joined in her small group by Edtih T. and Catherine Natawadiika. Edtih T. has a poultry business and wants to increase her stock. Catherine Natawadiika is currently operating a bar and hotel business and wants a loan to purchase a fridge.
